indicators.justification:
The data published by the Superintendency of Companies does not refer directly to the concept of beneficial ownership, however they allow to consult the names of the people who are shareholders of the companies, and find in which other companies they have participation. Hence, the personal data of the beneficiaries or addresses are not included, but these can be queried at the Internal Revenue Service website.

Portal de Información Superintendencia de Compañías [1] [2].

Sources:
[1] - https://appscvsmovil.supercias.gob.ec/PortalInfor/consultaPrincipal.zul
[2] - https://appscvs1.supercias.gob.ec/consultaPersona/consulta_cia_param.zul

indicators.justification:
The article 55 of the Organic Code of Territorial Organization, Autonomy and Decentralization (COOTAD) [1] establishes the exclusive competence of the municipalities to exercise control over the use and occupation of land in the canton and to prepare and administer urban and rural real estate cadastres. This implies that urban and rural land ownership data is managed by municipalities. Regarding data publication, some municipalities in the country have geoportals where they publish certain data on land use and cadastral codes [2]; however, data on land ownership is not published, so this information is not available online.

Sources:
[1] - https://www.cpccs.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/cootad.pdf
[2] - Quito's Geoportal - http://geoportal.quito.gob.ec/smiq/

evidence.title: Organic Code of Territorial Organization, Autonomy and Decentralization (COOTAD)

indicators.justification:
The Organic Law of Transparency and Access to Public Information [1] highlights that all the State institutions that make up the public sector will disseminate information through an information portal or web page, among which is, total information about the annual budget administered by the institution, specifying income, expenses, financing and operating results in accordance with budget classifiers, as well as budget settlement, specifying recipients of the delivery of public resources.

Sources:
[1] - https://www.oas.org/juridico/PDFs/mesicic5_ecu_ane_cpccs_22_ley_org_tran_acc_inf_pub.pdf

evidence.title: Organic Law of Transparency and Access to Public Information 1

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
Although the Official Public Procurement System [1] allows consulting the data of the public procurement processes carried out in the State, it does not include tools to compare historical prices for similar contracts, or even to review the purchasing behavior of each contracting entity. On the other hand, the Public Procurement Service began in 2020 the publication of data in an open format under Open Contracting, but only for data related to the contracting carried out during the health emergency of COVID-19.

[1] https://www.compraspublicas.gob.ec/ProcesoContratacion/compras/
[2] 
https://portal.compraspublicas.gob.ec/sercop/datos_abiertos/

evidence.title: Open Contracting Data of Public Procurement System

Procurement related to goods and services is included.
Procurement related to public works is included.

The tender stage is covered.

Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.

indicators.justification:
The Open Data Policy Guide [1] refers to the fact that central government entities must develop an internal communications plan that promotes supply as well as demand, facilitating the reuse and consumption of data; and raising awareness of the benefits, though this applies only to central government entities and will be executed after the closing date of this study.

[1] - https://www.gobiernoelectronico.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/ACUERDO-35-2020-Guia-datos-abiertos-11-12-2020-signed-signed-signes-signed.pdf

responses.response_text: There is isolated evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse?
There is evidence of government efforts to support open government data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support big data reuse in a general sense.
There is evidence of government efforts to support private sector or NGO data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support crowdsourced data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse from various data topics.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by civil society organizations.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by media.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector.
Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.
Government support for data reuse involves hackathons.
Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

responses.response_text: Support is given in one or more localities, but there are many other localities without such support, or with support of a lesser quality.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the support assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Open Government National Action Plan [1], the open data policy [2] and its guide [3] , have scope for the national government, so it is not mandatory for local governments to apply these.

[2] - https://www.gobiernoelectronico.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/ACUERDO-35-2020-Guia-datos-abiertos-11-12-2020-signed-signed-signes-signed.pdf
[3] - https://www.gobiernoelectronico.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Acuerdo-Poli%CC%81tica-Datos-Abiertos-17.04.20-v4-signed.pdf

responses.response_text: The open data initiative covers only a limited part of the national government, or only covers one or more sub-national governments.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely does this, or similar, open data initiatives apply?

indicators.justification:
The Open Data Index of Cities [1] prepared by Fundapi reflects that the majority of the 100 local governments evaluated regarding the publication of data show weaknesses in relation to data formats and availability.
[1] - https://indice.datosabiertos.ec/

responses.response_text: There is evidence of limited or ad-hoc capability to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent do city, regional, and local governments have the capability to effectively manage data?
There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.
There is evidence of local governments having current open data policies in place.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: The examples given are exceptions: the majority of cities and regions do not have the capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
Although there are commitments within the Open Government Action Plan [1] that contemplate training public servants on issues related to open data, some of these activities occurred after the closing date of this study.

[1] - https://www.opengovpartnership.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Ecuador_Action-Plan_2019-2022_Revised_ES.pdf

Training is planned by an established training team, department, or agency.
Public servants receive a certification when taking a training so there is a formal recognition as a professional development.

There is minimal interoperability between data generated by different entities.

responses.response_text: The datasets use a limited number of common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is minimal consistency; at least one category of identifiers is consistent across two datasets.
responses.subquestion_text: To what degree do the datasets associated with this theme use consistent identifiers and identification systems for elements that appear in more than one dataset?

indicators.justification:
The General Rules for the Institutions of the Finance System [1] establishes in article 15 that it is the permanent duty of the institutions of the financial system to identify the final beneficiary(s) of all the products they supply, which in all cases will be a natural person. Also that it is the responsibility of the financial system institution to monitor all the transactions of the accounts kept in the institution. Special attention will merit those commercial customer accounts that third parties accredit as a payment channel for the acquisition of goods or services. Additionally, Resolution No. SCV-DNCDN-14-017 [2] mentions that information about the list of administrators and partners of companies must be available for the public.

Sources:
[1] - https://www.superbancos.gob.ec/bancos/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2017/06/L1_XIII_cap_IV.pdf
[2] - https://portal.supercias.gob.ec/wps/portal/Inicio/Inicio/SectorSocietario/Normativa/Resoluciones

evidence.title: General Rules for the Institutions of the Finance System

indicators.justification:
There's no framework related to data collection and publication accesible to people with disabilities. Though, there is the Ecuadorian Technical Regulation RTE INEN 288 "Accesibility for web content" [1] mandatory for public entities that establishes the accessibility of information on government websites for people with disabilities.

Sources:
[1] - https://www.normalizacion.gob.ec/buzon/reglamentos/RTE-288.pdf

indicators.justification:
Ecuador's Open Data Policy [1], which relates to this Manual, is mandatory for entities dependent on the executive branch. On the other hand, the Law on the Public Data Registry System [2] includes guidelines for data registration, limited to the data managed by the Civil Registry, Property, Commercial, Corporate, Vehicle, ships and aircraft, patents, intellectual property data records credit and those currently or in the future determined by the National Directorate of Public Data Registry.

Sources:
[1] - https://www.telecomunicaciones.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Acuerdo-Politica-Datos-Abiertos-17.04.20-v4-signed.pdf
[2] - https://www.telecomunicaciones.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Ley-Organica-del-Sistema-Nacional-de-Registro-de-Datos-Publicos.pdf

evidence.title: Manual para Construcción de Portafolio Institucional de Datos Abiertos

responses.response_text: A framework exists but lacks full force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed apply to a limited number of departments or localities.
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly is good data management practice established?

indicators.justification:
Certain entities that manage data have information sharing agreements that must be signed by people who want to use them. For example, the National Institute of Statistics and Censuses (INEC) has a format of Agreement for the Use of Statistical Geographic Information [1]; the Ministry of Agriculture has a Confidentiality Agreement that applies to the use of information [Attached]; and the National Public Procurement Service has Terms of Use of the Public Procurement System that restrict the sharing of system information [2]. But there is no national framework for data sharing.

Sources:
[1] Acuerdo de uso de Información Geográfica Estadística - https://www.ecuadorencifras.gob.ec/documentos/web-inec/Flash/Cartografia/Contenido%20Cartograf%eda/POLITICAS%20Y%20ACUERDOS%20DE%20USO/ACUERDO%20DE%20USO%20INSTITUCIONAL%20DE%20INFORMACION%20CARTOGRAFICA_ABRIL2015.pdf
[2] Términos de Uso y Condiciones de Privacidad en el Portal -  https://www.compraspublicas.gob.ec/ProcesoContratacion/compras/FO/paso1.cpe

evidence.title: Acuerdo de Uso Información Cartográfica - INEC

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

indicators.justification:
Until May 1, 2021, the Personal Data Protection Law [1] was under discussion in the National Assembly, not in force. The protection of personal data during the period May 1, 2019 - May 1, 2021, was addressed in different regulations, although without specificity. Among these regulations, there is the Constitution of Ecuador [2], the Electronic Commerce Law [3], the Telecommunications Law [4], the Monetary Code [5].

Sources:
[1] Personal Data Protection Law proposal - https://www.dinardap.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2021/05/informe_final_para_segundo_debate_de_lopdpfw.pdf
[1] Constitution of Ecuador - https://www.presidencia.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/a2_1_constitucion_mar_2018.pdf
[2] Electronic Commerce Law - https://www.telecomunicaciones.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2012/11/Ley-de-Comercio-Electronico-Firmas-y-Mensajes-de-Datos.pdf
[3] Telecommunications Law - https://www.telecomunicaciones.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/downloads/2016/05/Ley-Org%C3%A1nica-de-Telecomunicaciones.pdf
[4] Monetary Code - http://www.pge.gob.ec/documents/Transparencia/antilavado/REGISTROOFICIAL332.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Organic Law of Transparency and Access to Public Information [1] highlights that all the State institutions that make up the public sector will disseminate information through an information portal or web page, among which is, total information about the annual budget administered by the institution, specifying income, expenses, financing and operating results in accordance with budget classifiers, as well as budget settlement, specifying recipients of the delivery of public resources.

Sources:
[1] - https://www.oas.org/juridico/PDFs/mesicic5_ecu_ane_cpccs_22_ley_org_tran_acc_inf_pub.pdf

evidence.title: Organic Law of Transparency and Access to Public Information

evidence.title: Portal de Información Superintendencia de Compañías

responses.response_text: One or more products/services exist, but they do not appear to make use of open datasets.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification: There's no evidence that land data is being used to influence policy in the interests of equitable and inclusive land tenure and use.
indicators.indicator_name: Use (L): Influencing policy for gender and inclusion
indicators.indicator_name_medium: Gender and inclusion uses of data
indicators.indicator_name_short: Gender and inclusion uses of data

responses.response_text: No evidence of actors or entities using this data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data

indicators.justification: There is no evidence of political integrity data being used to identify, expose, or highlight failures of government.

responses.response_text: No evidence of actors or entities using this data for accountability purposes.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
During the pandemic, projects were created using public procurement open data, from the government and civil society, like the ones mentioned, in example:

https://www.comprasabiertas.org/ - Project created by Fundapi, a non profit organization, using OCDS data.
https://portal.compraspublicas.gob.ec/sercop/datos_abiertos/ - Dashboards created by government.

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.indicator_name: Capability (C): Political freedoms and civil liberties
Capability (C): Business use of digital tools
Capability (C): Use of standards and methods in statistic offices
Use (U): Data use by international organizations
